title: Epiglottitis (Epiglottis Infection)
author: Stephanie Langmaid

sections.heading: What Is Epiglottitis?
content: Epiglottitis is a condition in which swelling deep inside your throat blocks your airway, making it hard or impossible to breathe. It's a medical emergency, and if not treated quickly, you could die.

Your epiglottis is a piece of cartilage at the base of your tongue . It flaps down when you swallow, to keep food and liquid from entering your windpipe. It can become inflamed and swollen, usually because of an infection or injury.

Epiglottitis used to mainly affect young children before there was a vaccine against Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), which was responsible for most cases. Now it's more common in adults, although it's rare overall.
It's much more dangerous in children because of the shape, size, and flexibility of their airways.
Your epiglottis closes off your trachea (windpipe) when you swallow so you don't breathe in food or liquid. If it's swollen, it can block your air supply. (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Causes
content: Epiglottitis usually comes from an infection. You're more likely to get it if you have immune system problems, or if you haven't had the Hib vaccine. The most common causes are bacteria, including:
bullets: Streptococcus groups A, B, and C

content: Less often, the infection that leads to epiglottitis can be caused by a fungus, particularly a yeast called Candida albicans or a mold called Aspergillus . That's more likely in people with immune system problems.
Sometimes, being sick with a virus allows a bacterial infection to take hold. You might get epiglottitis after you've had chickenpox or been infected with herpes simplex or Epstein-Barr.
Another, less common, cause is a burn or other injury to the back of the throat. This can come from:
Epiglottitis can also be a side effect of cancer treatment or another disease.
Is epiglottitis contagious?

Some of the infections that lead to epiglottitis can spread through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes. It's smart to do what you can to protect yourself and your family from upper respiratory diseases, such as washing your hands often and staying away from people who are sick.
bullets: Swallowing or choking on an object

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Symptoms
content: Epiglottitis usually develops very quickly. It often starts like an upper respiratory infection with a sudden, severe sore throat. Symptoms can go from mild to life-threatening in just a few hours.
4 D's of epiglottitis
Doctors sometimes refer to the most common symptoms of epiglottitis as the 4 D's, which stand for:
Other symptoms include:
Someone with epiglottitis may lean forward or tilt their chin up to make it easier to get air in. You may not be able to breathe at all if you lie down.
Watch for any of these warning signs if your child has an upper respiratory infection.
When to seek medical care

Epiglottitis is an emergency. Call 911 or go to the nearest emergency room if you think you or your child is experiencing the 4 D's. A blue color to the skin, called cyanosis, is a particularly urgent sign.

It's important to get help as quickly as possible to ensure the airway stays open. Don't try to look in your child's throat or put anything in their mouth at home. That can cause even more swelling. Do your best to keep your child calm and in an upright position to make breathing easier.
bullets: High-pitched whistling sound when you breathe in (stridor)

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Diagnosis
content: To diagnose epiglottitis, a doctor will need to examine your epiglottis, which can be risky. The swelling could suddenly close off your windpipe. It's especially a concern for children, as their airway and throat structures are smaller.

Doctors will watch you closely while they're diagnosing you, with machines monitoring your breathing and oxygen levels. They may take you into an operating room or intensive care area while they examine your throat in case an emergency situation develops.
They may look at your epiglottis with a special camera on a tube threaded down to your throat through your nose. This is called a laryngoscopy. They may also take X-rays of your neck and chest.
If you aren't getting enough oxygen, they may need to put a tube into your lungs to help you breathe.
They'll also run tests to find out what's causing the inflection. That may include:

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Misdiagnosis
content: Despite modern technology, epiglottitis is not easy to diagnose. It's often mistaken for strep throat or croup .

content_blocks.text: Despite modern technology, epiglottitis is not easy to diagnose. It's often mistaken for strep throat or croup .

sections.heading: Epiglottitis vs. croup
content: Both epiglottitis and croup can cause hoarseness and a whistling sound when you breathe. But croup tends to affect younger children and come on more gradually than epiglottitis does. Croup causes swelling farther down in your respiratory system, below your epiglottis, and brings on a distinctive barking cough. It doesn't usually cause drooling or trouble swallowing.
Other conditions epiglottitis may be confused with include:
bullets: An abscess (pocket of pus) in your tonsils or back of your throat

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Treatment
content: If you have epiglottitis, you need to be admitted to the hospital right away. Doctors have to make sure your airway stays open. Treatment includes:
Supplemental oxygen. You or your child will probably be given oxygen through a mask as long as you aren't struggling to breathe.

Breathing help. If swelling is in danger of cutting off your air supply, doctors may put a tube down your nose or mouth into your windpipe and leave it there for several days until the swelling goes down. That's called intubation. Rarely, if your throat is already too swollen, doctors may need to make a small cut in the outside of your throat to insert a breathing tube. That's called a cricothyroidotomy.

sections.heading: Antibiotics.
content: Doctors will usually give you an antibiotic as soon as possible through a needle placed into a vein, called an IV. They may start with a drug that works on the most common kinds of bacteria. If tests identify which germ is causing the infection, they may change the drug to one specifically targeted to fight that bacteria.
IV fluids. Until you're able to swallow normally, you'll get fluid through your IV.
Corticosteroids . These can be used to bring down swelling.
Treatment follow-up

Take all antibiotics and any other medication you may be prescribed exactly as your doctor tells you to. Keep all follow-up appointments with the doctor — and with the surgeon if a breathing tube was placed through your neck. The surgeon will remove the tube and make sure the site is healing well. Call your doctor right away or go back to the hospital if you have any problems.

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Complications
content: The main complication of epiglottitis is a blocked airway that makes it hard or impossible to breathe. Your body can't get enough oxygen, which may lead to death.
The bacteria responsible for epiglottitis could also spread to other parts of your body. That can lead to:
Other possible complications of epiglottitis include fluid in your lungs and a collapsed lung.

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Vaccine
content: Epiglottitis can often be prevented with proper vaccination against Hib infection. It's part of the recommended childhood vaccine series. Depending on the formulation, babies get it at the age of either 2 and 4 months or 2, 4, and 6 months, plus a booster at 12-15 months.

In older children and adults, Hib infection is rare, so if someone doesn't get the vaccine series by age 5, it's generally not recommended. The exception is people with immune system problems. You might need the vaccine if you:
If someone is diagnosed with Hib, anyone who lives with them or has close contact should take the antibiotic rifampin to avoid getting it.
bullets: Have sickle cell anemia or HIV

sections.heading: Epiglottitis Outlook
content: If it's caught and treated in time, most people will recover fully from epiglottitis. You may need to spend a week in the hospital.
But if someone doesn't get to the hospital early or is not correctly diagnosed and treated, they could become permanently injured or die. L ess than 1% of epiglottitis cases are fatal, however.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Epiglottitis is swelling of the piece of cartilage at the back of your throat that closes off your windpipe to keep food out when you swallow. The most common cause is a bacterial infection. Symptoms include pain when you swallow and a squeaking sound when you breathe. Epiglottitis is an emergency that needs immediate treatment to keep the swelling from blocking your air supply.

sections.heading: Epiglottitis FAQs
content: What are the risk factors for epiglottitis?

The main cause of epiglottitis is the Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria. You're most at risk if you haven't been vaccinated against it or if you have a weakened immune system. Other things that increase your odds of getting epiglottitis include being male, middle-aged, overweight, or having diabetes.

sections.heading: What is the home remedy for swollen epiglottis?
content: You should not attempt to take care of a swollen epiglottis at home. The condition can get worse quickly, and your breathing could suddenly be cut off. Call 911 or get to an emergency room right away if you or your child is having symptoms of epiglottitis.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Epiglottitis is swelling of the piece of cartilage at the back of your throat that closes off your windpipe to keep food out when you swallow. The most common cause is a bacterial infection. Symptoms include pain when you swallow and a squeaking sound when you breathe. Epiglottitis is an emergency that needs immediate treatment to keep the swelling from blocking your air supply.

sections.heading: Epiglottitis FAQs
content: What are the risk factors for epiglottitis?

The main cause of epiglottitis is the Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria. You're most at risk if you haven't been vaccinated against it or if you have a weakened immune system. Other things that increase your odds of getting epiglottitis include being male, middle-aged, overweight, or having diabetes.
